questions.question_text: Which of the following filesystem types has native read/write support on all desktop operating systems?

discussion.content:
NTFS, FAT = Windows
NFS, EXT 3, EXT 4 = Linux (usually)
HFS = MAC
EXFAT = USB (Windows, Linux)
FAT 32 = Almost all OS (like you said)

From what ive gathered, 
NTFS = Windows only
REFS = Not on MAC
FAT32 = ALMOST all OS
EXT4 = Read only on MAC

The question only states the tech tested the WLAN in the lobby. It does not state there is only 1 WAP for the whole site so another could still be down.
This question is not well-written either way.
Not sure if D but i guess if some devices failing then the WAP can be one of them
Not D, it says " A technician tests wireless connectivity in the lobby and is able to connect successfully." WAP:Wireless Access Point.

comments.content: The tech was able to connect in the lobby but the problem is in the warehouse. D is correct.

Read the question again. Some of you are worse than the incorrect answers this site gives.
***Several mobile users are reporting issues connecting to the WLAN within a warehouse

choices.A: SSID is configured to not broadcast.
choices.D: The WAP in the warehouse is down.

questions.question_text:
Several mobile users are reporting issues connecting to the WLAN within a warehouse. A technician tests wireless connectivity in the lobby and is able to connect successfully. Mobile users can connect to the Internet using cellular service, but they cannot access any internal resources on the WLAN. The technician received alerts of devices failing throughout the network due to a power outage.
Which of the following is MOST likely causing the wireless issues?

A user tries to open a client/server application, but a prompt appears for the username and password. The user is able to open and use the email client with no issues. The user's workstation is a loaner laptop. Everyone at the company is given administrator rights on their individual workstations.
Which of the following is MOST likely preventing the user from running this program?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct option is **D. UAC (User Account Control)**.

UAC is a security feature in Windows that helps prevent unauthorized changes to the system. It does this by asking for permission or an administrator's credentials before allowing actions that could potentially affect the system's operation or that change settings that affect other users. If the user is trying to run a client/server application that requires administrative privileges, UAC could be prompting for the username and password. The other options (EFS, NTFS, UTP) are not directly related to the scenario described. EFS (Encrypting File System) and NTFS (New Technology File System) are related to file systems, and UTP (Unshielded Twisted Pair) is a type of cabling used in networking. None of these would typically cause a prompt for a username and password when running an application.
I'm not sure about this but UAC [User Access Control] is one of things that stops a user from accessing certain programs/data, so it makes sense that UAC is preventing you from doing stuff

questions.question_text:
A technician is working on a computer that has the following symptoms:
* Unable to access the Internet
* Unable to send email
* Network connection (limited or no connectivity)
The technician runs hardware diagnostics on the computer and verifies the computer's NIC is functioning correctly. The technician attempts to access the Internet and receives the message: page cannot be displayed. The technician runs a command to verify the computer network settings and sees the following information:

IP address: 192.168.0.100 -

Subnet mask: 255.255.255.0 -

Gateway: 192.168.0.1 -

DNS: 192.168.0.1 -
The technician confirms other computers on the network can access the Internet.
Which of the following is MOST likely causing the issues?

discussion.content:
D. Proxy Settings is correct.
Logic: Firewalls can be local to the device, but is more likely to be the network's firewall. Since the question states that other users can connect just fine, this can not be a firewall setting. The firewall setting would force drop the traffic altogether and not cause "limited or no internet access".

With that in mind, this is means that the issue is local to the device, which would point to local proxy settings being the issue.

Selected Answer: D
Proxy seems correct since it can change the IP address and cause limited connectivity
it seems like this is firewall rule.
How is this a proxy setting? I dont understand prixy

comments.content:
doesn't explain why there is no email, or why there is limited network connectivity?
Proxy settings are usually manipulated via the client browser. I can understand if the entire proxy SERVER is down. it still doesn't make. I have a feeling question like these are memorised and parsed to dumbs incorrectly
In corporate they usually use proxy to access internet. Since the IP and gateway are correct, most likely the proxy is not loaded thats why he cant access the internet.

in my opinion, since other users can connect to internet, so the firewall and proxy (that is implemented in separate server) are ok... so the problem is local at user computer... most of the time in computer end user you can change proxy setting but not for firewall.

choices.C: Restore the system using the last known-good configuration from the recovery console.
choices.F: Ensure endpoint protection is up to date and run the utility to remove the threat.
choices.E: Educate the user on verifying email links by hovering over them before clicking.
choices.B: Update the host firewall to block port 80 on the workstation.
choices.D: Ensure antivirus is up to date and install the latest patches.
choices.A: Ensure the anti-rootkit utility is up to date and run it to remove the threat.

questions.question_text:
A technician is removing malware from a workstation. The malware was installed via a phishing attack, which was initiated from a link that was included in an email.
Which of the following should the technician do to address this issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
must be D,E

I just don't get it, in the 7 step of comptia's malware removal, there is no "restore", step 6 is basically about "creating a new restore point" and not restoring. So it must be D,E. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

Selected Answer: CE
All C, D and E makes sense here but a previous similar question mentioned restoring to an earlier point too , so I'll go with C and E

Updating antivirus is more of prevention before any attack occurs. Addressing the issue at hand (given the options) would be a restore from last know good configuration and educating so it doesn’t happen again.

For Malware removal, steps taken from the course note:

CompTIA has identified a seven-step best practice procedure for malware removal:
1. Identify and research malware symptoms.
2. Quarantine infected systems.
3. Disable System Restore (in Windows).
4. Remediate infected systems:
• Update anti-malware software.
• Scan and use removal techniques (Safe Mode, Pre-installation environment).
5. Schedule scans and run updates.
6. Enable System Restore and create restore point (in Windows).
7. Educate end user.

basically i believed the ans can be run the endpoint protection to remove the threat and educate user too.

Last known good configuration as far as I know will only deal with malware, potentially, where the malware has affects the ability for the PC to start. 

There are two possible suggestions in the options strictly to deal with removal and one that deals with prevention. Updated antivirus and endpoint management and scan. Prevention would be educated users. Unfortunately the question is vague and asks about "this issue". Is it the removal of the malware or the fact that phishing was used? If we go with both then educate is one and one of the two removal techniques make the most sense.
